title: 115_hr275
content: The "Fairness for Crime Victims Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title. Point of order against certain changes in mandatory programs affecting the Crime Victims Fund. The Crime Victims Fund, created in 1984, is funded by fines, penalties, forfeited bonds, and private donations, with no taxpayer dollars. Funds are used to provide services to victims of crime. The Crime Victims Fund, established in 1984, is used to provide services to crime victims as per the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. However, Congress has been withholding over $10 billion from victims of various crimes, including child abuse, sexual assault, and domestic violence, by not disbursing the full amount collected. From fiscal year 2010 to 2014, only 30% of the $12 billion collected was distributed to crime victims, despite budget rules indicating that the previously spent money is still in the Fund. Congress concludes that funds collected by the Crime Victims Fund should be used for services to crime victims in accordance with the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. "Congress establishes a point of order against changes in mandatory programs affecting the Crime Victims Fund." The term 'CHIMP' refers to a provision that would impact direct spending or receipts under the Balanced Budget Act, resulting in a net decrease in budget authority. The term 'Crime Victims Fund' is defined as the fund for crime victims. The term 'Crime Victims Fund' refers to the fund established under the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. The term '3-year average amount' is the annual average deposited into the fund over a 3-fiscal-year period. In the Senate, a point of order can be raised against a provision containing a CHIMP that would decrease budget authority. If a provision in a bill would reduce the amount available from the Crime Victims Fund below the 3-year average, a point of order can be raised in the Senate. If sustained, the provision will be removed and cannot be offered as an amendment. This point of order can also be raised during the consideration of conference reports or House amendments. In the Senate, a point of order can be raised against a conference report or House amendment, leading to a debate on whether to recede from the amendment or concur with a further amendment. The subsection can only be waived by a supermajority vote. In the Senate, a point of order can be raised against a conference report or House amendment, requiring a three-fifths vote to waive or suspend the subsection. Budgetary levels are determined based on estimates provided by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the Senate. In the House of Representatives, a provision in a bill proposing appropriations for a fiscal year that would cause a reduction in available funds can be challenged. The House of Representatives cannot consider amendments or conference reports on bills that would reduce the amount available from the Crime Victims Fund below the 3-year average, based on estimates provided by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget. The House of Representatives cannot consider amendments or conference reports on bills that would reduce the amount available from the Crime Victims Fund below the 3-year average, based on estimates provided by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget. A technical and conforming amendment is made to the table of contents in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Point of order against changes in mandatory programs affecting the Crime Victims Fund.
